Comment: Larsen opening, that I have played (but not mastered) a couple of times, but never with black.

...and yet, I go for the risky e4, will have this pen pinned if not taking care of it properly. There is nothing wrong with it, but d4 is more relaxing, although it leaves the a1-h8 diagonal for the WB.

Nc6 is also normal here. Then white goes for e3 and then Bb5 pinning the defending N. It seems to me 2...d6 is weaker, as the white contested to it, but maybe I just played a horrible defence (most likely)

Now if 3...exd4; 4.Bxd4, Nc6 Black seems to be alright to me. In case of 4.Nf3, Nc6 same story.
And I realized of the compromised situation after this move. So much for an "experienced" (limited) Larsen player of me.

This seems to me that slows down the development, but looks alright since it also attacks b7 and with x-ray the R in a8. A potential pain in the neck.
I can always faint the Ng4 here if needed, but doesn't lead to anything. Hope white does pay more attention to the jumper than it deserves.

Leaving the mentioned b7 undefended, but it seems alright so far. And yet, it really mad me feel it compromised black's attack because of the threats on that diagonal. but I must find compensation for my disadvantage and start attacking. Maybe 11...Bh3+ prior Be6 was better.

Not many jumps for this N, since c4 is defended by my bishop. And it is not going anywhere, even being a powerful central N. Moreover, it blocks the WB diagonal, relieving pressure there.
Chaaarge!!
Trying to help with the defence. Rooks can now slide to "a" column and BB can be expelled from b4 if allowed.
So do not waste time, keep on pushing, black!
And here is why I posted this game. A beautiful combination arises.
Allows WR to enter the fatal 2nd (7th) line. Risky, but I must admit I didn't see a definitive attack yet, just the feeling I had to get something here by doubling rooks on the "a" column.
